name: Jennifer W. Graham
affiliation: Syracuse University, Department of Electrical Engineering & Computer Science

top_primary_author_publications.title: Applications of biaxially anisotropic media in review
top_primary_author_publications.abstract: This paper provides a review of the work to date in the area of applications of biaxially anisotropic materials in RF devices.
top_primary_author_publications.venue: IEEE Conference on Antenna Measurements and Applications

top_primary_author_publications.title: Electromagnetic Waves in Biaxially Anisotropic Media
top_primary_author_publications.abstract: The article presents an overview of the wave behavior, governing equations, and some applications of biaxially anisotropic media. As this area of research matures, the governing behaviors described here will be of utmost importance to the understanding of device behavior.

top_primary_author_publications.title: Rectangular patch antennas on biaxial substrates
top_primary_author_publications.abstract: Rectangular patch antennas are modeled using arbitrarily oriented biaxially anisotropic substrates. The Method of Moments is used to compute induced currents and the results are used to calculate input impedance, resonant length, impedance bandwidth and radiation patterns.

top_secondary_author_publications.title: Fields and Wave Modes Analysis of Rectangular Waveguide Filled With Uniaxial Medium
top_secondary_author_publications.abstract: A rectangular waveguide filled with a uniaxial medium is treated. Different orientations of the optic axis are considered, and the transmission characteristics of the guided waves are studied.
top_secondary_author_publications.venue: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques

top_secondary_author_publications.title: Automating the Shared Resource Laboratory Using Computer Scripts: A Case Report
top_secondary_author_publications.abstract: Shared resource laboratories (SRLs) offer instrumentation, training, and support to investigators and play an important role in the progress and development of science.
